title: Morello puts the Lore situation into perspective at PAX
body:
I had figured this was the case for a while now, but people seem to think they just don't care.

They DO care, they just made mistakes getting there.

replies.body:
Fool me once, joke's on me, Ignore the community** for a consecutive year ** and the flame's on you ...


Read Jaredan's post where he flat out tells us he gives zero f*cks about our opinion and weep...

Found it. Here you go:

http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/f/6kFXY1kR/d/Qr1AicQh?comment=0032

Which came from this post, also talking about Jaredan's response:
http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/story-art/ye9b8JYQ-thanks-for-the-response-jaredan-but-im-now-completely-destroyed-as-a-fan-of-league


+1 for detective work.

I didn't get that feeling at all. "Talking about already created stories and characters, talking about the essences of people and places of Runeterra, it's all good." They are happy to take ideas on what people think makes a champion. What they won't do is take the stories that fans write and make them canon. People are twisting the meaning of his words far too much.

From my past lurking days on this board, it seems that in the olden days, part of what was once fan-fiction helped establish the canon (Supposedly, the story behind Lulu's and Vlad's friendship was based on a forum post that was fan-fiction). Unfortunately, I have no way to prove this.

What people don't like is the following:
> There are just certain things we can respond to and other things we can't. It's not as much the topic as it is the way we engage about it. I know Ant in Oz riled some folks when saying that we can't read fan-fiction. I can understand how that might appear, but it's just a truth of being a professional writer. It's partly due to the legality of it, **but also because using other people's ideas, even accidentally, is stomach churning to a creative writer.**

Had he stopped at where it was due to the legality of the situation, people would've been more okay with it. Not by much, but it was a fairly logical reason. But to say that it's offensive to a creative writer to use other people's ideas opens a can of worms he didn't realize, for a few reasons:
-A fair number of skins, and some champions, are inspired in some way by previous works.
-The claim I made earlier (someone else would have to confirm this for me), that fanfiction or other such ideas that was provided by the community was made in the final product.
-There's a DAMN BOARD for champion/skin concepts. Which means, at some point, a Rioter had to have looked at it and said "Huh, that's interesting"

Had his words been warped? I believe it has to a degree. Is the community wrong for being angry at those words? Not in the slightest.
Besides, he can always come back and rectify. Nobody except Riot itself can stop him.

Any professional writer, in any creative industry, does their best to avoid stealing stories from other people, even accidentally. There are always influences, but each piece needs to be its own unique take from the writer or writers working on it.

I'm fully aware of the can of worms as some players had already reacted negatively to Ant in Oz's post, but it's still a fact and I didn't want to avoid it.

The words "stomach churning" are in regard to the idea of a writer accidentally using someone else's ideas and then realizing it later. A creative writer's job is to come up with stories and execute on them, taking those ideas from elsewhere is something we avoid as much as possible for a variety of reasons. As has been outlined.

We can talk about our champions, who they are, what makes them tick , the aspects of them we want to explore, and what it is about them that fuels your passion, that you find enthralling. We cannot take your ideas for the specific ways we exemplify those characteristics through story.

[Can we talk about the changing/replacing of champions?](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/story-art/LtBeg85P-characters-in-the-new-lore) 

I lost faith in the lore and all willingness to invest into the new lore when one of my favorite characters got removed. As far as I know, Riot still stands by that decision. Why should I care about a lore where my favorite character got and could get retconned for a new one tomorrow?

Beside that, I don't feel like any community input is considered at all. You are just working behind curtains, doing everything internally and *sometimes *sending out a message "still working" or a finished event to the outside world. No feedback gathering or discussions other than internal seem to happen at all from what I see.

Last red post involving the community was a month ago, when Ant asked for community input on what champions people wanted to know more about. 

There was a few comments from Rioters, but honestly, it does feel insufficient when it comes to trying to understand the lore as it is now.

It is unfortunate there has been less lore posts on the main site; you can see more for DJ Sona skin than anything about the state of the lore as it is now.

> [{quoted}](name=Sneak Dog,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=L2nEKFGG,comment-id=0000000000010001000000000000,timestamp=2015-03-13T03:32:12.516+0000)
>
> [Can we talk about the changing/replacing of champions?](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/story-art/LtBeg85P-characters-in-the-new-lore) 
> 
> I lost faith in the lore and all willingness to invest into the new lore when one of my favorite characters got removed. As far as I know, Riot still stands by that decision. Why should I care about a lore where my favorite character got and could get retconned for a new one tomorrow?
> 
> Beside that, I don't feel like any community input is considered at all. You are just working behind curtains, doing everything internally and *sometimes *sending out a message "still working" or a finished event to the outside world. No feedback gathering or discussions other than internal seem to happen at all from what I see.

T -t-t-t-trunde ? :'(

Now, I'm no professional writer, but I do understand the need to keep your content "pure", in a sense. Yet, as I'm sure you're doing, whatever content you put out would be done with care; planning out every aspect as much as possible. 

But, don't you think it's a bit strange to be reacting this way to input? 
From what I've heard, every story out there has been told countless different ways. It's what you do with that story that makes it unique. Point in case: Wukong, the Monkey King {{champion:62}}. The name, title, and appearance has many people thinking of Sun Wukong from the Chinese classic *Journey to the West*. There's many renditions of him, yet the lore that pertains to him here for League of Legends places him in Runeterra, and makes him unique. I mention him because I feel under your words, and I may be misguided, but I feel that a champion such as Wukong wouldn't exist because that identity has already been established in previous works (or it'd give you a pretty bad case of "stomach churning").

If that example didn't work, here's one that might seem a bit more familiar to you: Kalista{{champion:429}}  and Graves{{champion:104}} . Based on lore, both are driven by revenge of those who have betrayed them. The details vary (some more vague than others, if you don't mind me saying), but it's the same story at its essence. 




As I mentioned in my comment that you've replied to, there's a board dedicated to Skin/Champion concepts. Now, if part of how you operate includes avoiding that section like the plague to avoid being tainted, that's fine. If we are able to speak about the bare essence of champions, that's fine. If we could maybe speak more about the world of Runeterra in general and get a better vibe of the realm that everyone exists in, that'd be wonderful. But, like I said earlier, it's on you and everyone on your team(s?) to come here and give us something.

Thanks for your time, Jaredan. Feel somewhat honored to have you reply to my comment.

> [{quoted}](name=Jaredan,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=L2nEKFGG,comment-id=000000000001000100000000,timestamp=2015-03-13T03:10:50.260+0000)

> We can talk about our champions, who they are, what makes them tick , the aspects of them we want to explore, and what it is about them that fuels your passion, that you find enthralling. We cannot take your ideas for the specific ways we exemplify those characteristics through story.

Forgive me but I find your words hollow.

All of the "talk" and yet somehow... Ashe, Trundle, Karma, Xert, and Cass all lost core aspects of their characterization that fans saw as the center of their personalities.

I'll even let Trundle slide as he does fits better in the world, not that old trundle would not have worked. I find it particular funny that you wished to tell "stories that continue", but were not skilled enough to tell the story of a troll traveling north then finding and taking over another troll tribe. 

Azri was almost a step in the right direction... and then you stopped telling the story.

I'll give credit that Sion was a roaring success... great work you guys did really well.

but then lets not forget the gem of Kalista, who promotes the act of killing yourself if it will make someone you hate pay... Good message, really nice.
 
3 for 8, a passing grade, does not make. 

You are placing yourself and your fellow writers on some mythical pedestal of "professional writer", But let me be frank. You are arrogant, and smug. In my opinion, your concept of limits on how a community can come together to interact and help with the development of lore are flawed in every regard. 

Even when operating under the restrictions you placed on the community engagement, your staff fail to capture the core of the characters highlighted above.

You give no thought to player agency in ether game or lore, the fact you would even see those as separate in a interactive medium such as gaming is baffling btw. You fail to tell a story that includes the game for which you write, and the whole of the community has suffered for it.

Your department engaged in ham-handed lies, and emotional manipulation of newer lore readers with false statements when discussing pros and cons of the old vs the new lore... then when called on it by older lore readers, Your people defended themselves by claiming ignorance of the subject for which they should be experts on.

Honestly... Your staff killed a great deal of love I had for this game.

If my words seem harsh realize, they are not typed with the intent to inflame. They are typed to highlight a problem you fail to see exist. But I doubt you can even read them from your seat so high up on that grand lofty spire of "professional writer".

***But that's just like my opinion man.***

> [{quoted}](name=Jaredan,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=L2nEKFGG,comment-id=000000000001000100000000,timestamp=2015-03-13T03:10:50.260+0000)

> We can talk about our champions, who they are, what makes them tick , the aspects of them we want to explore, and what it is about them that fuels your passion, that you find enthralling. 

This is impossible to do with the current state of lore.  Remember, you guys decided to delete it all because the IoW was "stifling your ability to write compelling stories".  That was almost a year ago, where are the compelling stories?  Aside from Sion, you haven't delivered anything.

Only a few champs have any real lore "hooks", most of them are just 2 short paragraphs of vagueness.  Such compelling, much wow.


> Talking about already created stories and characters

Yes, lets talk about the already created travesty that was the Shurima event.  Holy fuck that was bad.  This is the entire reason lore fans want to talk BEFORE you do these lore segments, because the stuff you guys come up with on your own is not worth the 30 seconds it takes to read.

> [{quoted}](name=Jaredan,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=L2nEKFGG,comment-id=000000000001000100000000,timestamp=2015-03-13T03:10:50.260+0000)
>
> Any professional writer, in any creative industry, does their best to avoid stealing stories from other people, even accidentally. There are always influences, but each piece needs to be its own unique take from the writer or writers working on it.

It sounds a bit strange to me you say "stealing", like people weren't giving their ideas for the exact purpose of you using them.
By the way, how do you feel about it when, example given, people say the Xerath, Renekton & Co. story is a Fullmetal Alchemist rip-off? (I don't even know the series, but read that claim here and there)

> **A creative writer's job is to come up with stories and execute on them**, taking those ideas from elsewhere is something we avoid as much as possible for a variety of reasons. As has been outlined.

Here I need to retain to not turn to flaming about how you retconned the entire setting that made the game.

> [{quoted}](name=Jaredan,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=L2nEKFGG,comment-id=000000000001000100000000,timestamp=2015-03-13T03:10:50.260+0000)
>
> Any professional writer, in any creative industry, does their best to avoid stealing stories from other people, even accidentally. There are always influences, but each piece needs to be its own unique take from the writer or writers working on it.
> 
> I'm fully aware of the can of worms as some players had already reacted negatively to Ant in Oz's post, but it's still a fact and I didn't want to avoid it.
> 
> The words "stomach churning" are in regard to the idea of a writer accidentally using someone else's ideas and then realizing it later. A creative writer's job is to come up with stories and execute on them, taking those ideas from elsewhere is something we avoid as much as possible for a variety of reasons. As has been outlined.
> 
> We can talk about our champions, who they are, what makes them tick , the aspects of them we want to explore, and what it is about them that fuels your passion, that you find enthralling. We cannot take your ideas for the specific ways we exemplify those characteristics through story.

Fair enough, when will you explain to us **WHY**our champions are fighting and why they are alone in doing it since there is NOTHING stopping Swain as an example for rolling in on SR with the ENTIRE NOXIAN GODDAMN WAR-MACHINE behind him ?

Il stop being a toxic douche when you actually give the community a valid response since you obliterated the universe we used to love an care for and has given us nothing but some fancy animations in its place.

But, with the massive community you deal with, at least some of us will have the same ideas as you, before you write them down even. You're also the only part of Riot that doesn't take that kind of feedback, like what the hell man, we have skins based on fan-content, but we can't have a say in the characters' stories? You work for Riot, the company track record goes against what you've been doing so far.

Also, did you go through with the retcon for this reason because Factions already did most of what you could think of with the Institute?

Could you explain a bit why the Narrative department has this particular policy while the other departments in Riot (specifically thinking about the various art departments) actively monitor and develop excellent fan concepts?  I understand the desire to produce something unique and own it but you already work within teams to iterate and rework concepts and stories - what makes the narrative department special and more pure than the rest of Riot which are happy and excited to involve the community in their work? 

Also, I think framing this as 'theft' is a terrible way of looking at the subject and, I think, fundamentally distorts your approach to the subject.  Any stories that fans generate are born out of passion and a desire to share and give back to the community - I can't imagine any fan being upset that their idea was incorporated or altered by Riot to be part of the 'canon lore'.  And from a legal standpoint there should be no difference than iterating on skin ideas produced by the community because (a) you already own the copyright on the champions and thus the fan-work would be infringing rather than the inverse and (b) you could add a 'terms of use' to the boards saying that players release any rights to stories, etc that are posted.

> [{quoted}](name=Jaredan,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=L2nEKFGG,comment-id=000000000001000100000000,timestamp=2015-03-13T03:10:50.260+0000)
> We can talk about our champions, who they are, what makes them tick , the aspects of them we want to explore, and what it is about them that fuels your passion, that you find enthralling. We cannot take your ideas for the specific ways we exemplify those characteristics through story.

Cool! Can we do the first thing, then? I dunno about anyone else, but that's what I'm asking.
Like how Ironstylus made those Taric threads.

> Any professional writer, in any creative industry, does their best to avoid stealing stories from other people, even accidentally.

Of course everyone tries to avoid stealing and wants to come up with their own material.  It's wrong to steal.  But the community is WILLINGLY offering their ideas to you, so no it's NOT stealing.  There's NOTHING wrong with incorporating ideas that are being suggested willingly to you, whether it's from a family, friend, stranger.  

> We cannot take your ideas for the specific ways we exemplify those characteristics through story.

Of course you can, don't pretend you can't. You're just choosing not to, which is arrogant.  What matters is producing good lore, and if using concepts that the community is offering lets us end up with a better story, then you should use them.  Have you seen the Imitation Game?  Brilliant as he was, he couldn't do it alone.  He needed everyone else's help.  FCK your goddamn pride, you want to win the War or not????

To add to your explanation, Terry Pratchett (may you be as marvelous in the next world as you were in this one, you magnificent bastard) and Stephen King both stated that the key to being a good writer is constantly reading other people's work and filling your head with ideas to the point of bursting. H.P. Lovecraft outright called himself a plagiarist who relies on interesting spins of other people's ideas to put food on his table.

Jaredan's wording basically made the lore team look like they're already considering themselves to be better than the greatest writers of our era despite having barely produced any literary work at this point.

There's a difference between taking ideas and putting your own spin on the idea, and just straight taking stories from another person. THAT is what is stomach churning, as is how ready people are to misinterpret words and blow them out of proportion.

And yet it somehow didn't stop the lore team from straight-up taking ideas from other sources, including forum goers (Vladimir says hello).

What Jaredan says is still contradictory to everything you'll learn in a creative writing class, and those words contradict the recent direction of the narrative on top of that.

I can't say anything about the 'including forum goers' other than to ask you to cite evidence that was the source of the idea. I wasn't around then.

However, I see no contradiction here. There is a difference between reading widely and collecting ideas from everywhere which you then use to inform your own writing, and reading other people's work within your own world, suggestions for plot points in your world, etc. I have never, ever seen a writer suggest reading fanfiction of your work for ideas. The closest analogue would be shared comics universes and being inspired by other work within the universe, but even then, that's now cannon for your universe so it is a different paradigm.

I don't think it's fan fictions not being used that people are irked about. It's the lack of input Narrative takes from the players, especially compared to the rest of Riot it seems. Also that Riot narrative in the past has been far more willing to consider ideas from players and actually allowed a limited role in the lore through the Journal of Justice and a few other things. Very limited, but still felt good to be part of.

There's a fine line here, though. There's a huge difference between something like "I'd like to hear about  Garen's childhood." and "Garen and Cassi should have been childhood friends, which is how he met Kat." The first is great and useful to narrative, the other is essentially fan fiction. Being able to contribute to the direction and highlight areas of interest is great, and Riot could likely do better at it- though they do have that huge thread asking what people are most interested in learning about in the Lore. The latter is what Jaredan is warning about.

> [{quoted}](name=LucidLunatic,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=L2nEKFGG,comment-id=00000000000100010000000100000000000000000001,timestamp=2015-03-13T15:39:30.497+0000)
>
> There's a fine line here, though. There's a huge difference between something like "I'd like to hear about  Garen's childhood." and "Garen and Cassi should have been childhood friends, which is how he met Kat." The first is great and useful to narrative, the other is essentially fan fiction. Being able to contribute to the direction and highlight areas of interest is great, and Riot could likely do better at it- though they do have that huge thread asking what people are most interested in learning about in the Lore. The latter is what Jaredan is warning about.

I don't think you get that nether of those is wrong. Both are very useful.

Childhood friends is a pretty broad term... childhood is a big range of age as well. What was the lvl of friendship. In how those thing play out, what do those things say about Garen, Cass, Demacia, Noxus, Lux, Kat, Kat's father, Garen's Father, the diplomatic relations between the two super powers.

You are clueless if you think real creative writers would find the suggestion *"Garen and Cassi should have been childhood friends, which is how he met Kat."* to be even remotely destructive... even if you don't use that idea the concepts behind it are very thought inspiring.

For the record I find "Garen and Cass should have been childhood friends, which is how he met Kat." to be a bad idea in terms of logistic. Cass is not really right in personality to even be friends with Garen. Also Kat is older than Cass.

My point though is that even with such a weak premises, the thought that come out of it are great for world building and character examination. If you can not see that, I suspect you do no creative writing yourself... Try some.

Totally agree that the logistics of my plot suggestion are awful :). Picked something arbitrary.

However, I think this is why the community and Jaredan et al may be in such disagreement. You place the line in very different places. For the record, I both do and have done a reasonable amount of creative writing. I've both taken courses, as well as have/had a presence on fanfiction.net, fictionpress, critique circle, etc. So it's perfectly possible to disagree while having creative writing experience, as should already be clear from Riot's stance.

The only environment where I, as a writer, would be comfortable with someone making plot suggestions, even on the level of the one I made, would be in a writing circle type environment, where I submitted a draft and wanted feedback on how to make the story stronger- how to hone my craft.

Here on the boards, we aren't being offered drafts. We are certainly not being asked to help the lore team improve as writers. While certain feedback is valuable from us, telling them how to do their jobs is not something they are looking to hear, and that includes our worldbuilding suggestions.

If a company is trying to make a product to satisfy its consumers, is it not a good idea to take feedback from the consumers? The rest of Riot as a company is pretty darn good at incorporating feedback from players. Most players aren't artists or game designers or economists, but their input is still vital as a whole. Art changes when people think something is ugly or doesn't match characters. Abilities change when people find them unsatisfying. The PBE exists for the purpose of taking feedback from players. There have been huge threads about what people want from champions like Skarner, Rengar and others. Of course not all player suggestions were enacted, but they were still considered and as a whole had some impact. 

Even in Lore plots and details have been changed from player feedback. The infamous Saturday Morning Cartoon Villain Viktor was changed after a furious response from players. In the Journal of Justice we interacted with the writers through fanmail and questions to champions. Often the writers would give us plot and character details because we asked for them. Nothing huge and Runeterra shaking, but still we influenced the lore. There are many other instances. 

To ignore such a strong precedent of player feedback shaping what the company creates is rather upsetting I think. What is it about Narrative that makes player suggestions anathema? Why is it bad for players to influence the lore, but not the game and art? Few of us are demanding to be given the reigns of Narrative to do what we want with it. Certainly no product can be made solely by anarchic committee (except maybe a Twitch Plays game). There needs to be a balance of Narrative control and player desires. Of course Narrative has final say and should have final say. Quality control is vital and they'll never please every single fan. They have a big picture view and are trained writers with more resources than us. But players are the ones reading the lore and it's designed to appeal to us. If we don't like it, then it should be changed. It's not us telling Narrative how do to its job I see happening most often. It's players saying 'We don't like this lore' and the response being 'We aren't going to change it.' If a world building suggestion is pleasing to many players and doesn't clash with the lore Narrative wishes to tell, what makes it a bad thing to listen to? We already are helping (hopefully) shape how champions like Taric will be remade. Taric is part of the world, and we are giving world building suggestions to shape him. 

It's a hard balance. Right now I don't think the balance is right though. Hmm...maybe Bard is here to save Lore.

> [{quoted}](name=LucidLunatic,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=L2nEKFGG,comment-id=0000000000010001000000010000000000000000000100000000,timestamp=2015-03-13T22:18:07.162+0000)

> Here on the boards, we aren't being offered drafts. We are certainly not being asked to help the lore team improve as writers. While certain feedback is valuable from us, telling them how to do their jobs is not something they are looking to hear, and that includes our worldbuilding suggestions.

And what you are failing to grasp is that there is no harm in hearing what we have to say. This is a game. One in which now we play directly as the characters.

Getting feedback on what we want those characters to be is not harmful.

"Plot suggestions" are in no way harmful... I fail to see how they could be. If you don't like the suggestion or it doesn't work you discard it. The real issue is that people who find there work to carry some kind of sacred quality often make the most pretentious twats in real life.

While I wont go as far as to say Narrative seem to be those people... The evidence is clear Narrative has already missed the mark several times on Characters. 

What narrative wants is for us all to STFU and just "Like" whatever they put out.

Well we don't do that when something is imbalanced in the game and we won't do it in Lore ether.

This is a game with 4 years of lore pre-retcon... and people are still attached to that lore. To give it up Narrative needed to show real flaws in it... and at the same time show a plan forward that would preserve the characters.

Narrative failed to show a real flaw, then time and time again failed to maintain the characters with respect to the originals.

No one talks about it... but new Karma is a direct affront to what the original character was all about. She make direct quotes that go against what her philosophy was before.

Now on the subject of input. Maybe you don't like input on your stories... and you are the type of writer that likes to give readers finished products with a "Here it is, read it, and if you don't like anything go fuck yourself" attitude. And that would be fine for most companies. But that isn't what the rest of Riot is about and it shouldn't be what Riot's Narrative is about.

I would put forward if their train of thought, or personal grasp of a setting is so weak that merely reading opinions of interesting ideas unhinges that grasp... perhaps they don't belong in a professional environment when it comes to writing.

Further more you want a real world example of something like this blowing up and costing a company REAL money... Mass Effect 3's ending.

Mass Effect 1, 2, & most of 3, where written with community input and feedback on so many levels, by 1000s of dedicated fans. 

Then it came time for the ending and you know how many people got to put their input into that?

2... 2 people... 2 Holy sages of the clan "Professional Writer" sat down behind closed doors with NDA's and wrote out the ending without any input from the fans... the ending had to be a surprise right?

I think we know how that turned out...

Indeed, but I think Narrative's connections to the players have significantly decreased over time. Even if Jaerdan is only referring to fan fictions, the diminished interaction is still present. The precedent for player lore interaction is still there as well and it rankles to be politely snubbed at times.
To be fair, HP Lovecraft is mostly known for the stories that didn't make him any real money or fame in the first place.

I feel it a bit more: There's great, and I mean really great fan works that exist out there (Factions being one of them), and when a post comes out like that, I get a sense it's like a subtle insult to those folks who make these fanfiction works about titles that they love, because they hold a title of "professional writer". 

Is there a code that needs to be followed? Sure. But, it doesn't feel like it holds weight because as you said, they've barely produced any literary work.
BTW, is there any supplemental lore besides what I see in the game for Bard? There was some champion teasers, but that's it really, and that champ, like many others, still feel lacking.
Wait, what the heck!?  Lulu and Vlad are friends?  When/Where/How did this happen (I know you said you couldn't find the fanfic, but where is this information currently)?
Someone stated this, and made a link to the old forums that showed the fanfic. I'd have to do a lot of searching on these boards to find the link for you. Give me time.

>"Talking about already created stories and characters, talking about the essences of people and places of Runeterra, it's all good." 

As the person who posted that other thread, I feel it necessary to explain how I reached my conclusion.

When I consider "already created stories" about League champions, all those stories have been *deleted* and what remains are placeholders for when Riot gets around to doing something about it (which is between Soonâ„¢ and never as far as we know).  Therefore, there's *nothing* to talk about on that front.

Considering "Essences of people and places of Runeterra," this is also up for grabs since the entire world of Runeterra is being rebuilt (supposedly).  Also, the "core concepts" of each and every champion in League should *already* be well ingrained within the minds of the people in Narrative.
If they're capable of missing the mark on a champion's core concepts (Xerath, for instance) when they release and establish a new story (thus, creating new canon for the lore), then what does debating these points *actually* accomplish?  Would Jaredan, Loping Cinder and the rest of Narrative be willing to go back and redo a champion's failed bio (changing months of internal debate we don't get to be a part of) after getting feedback from us?  I have my doubts.

So, I ask you, what would be the point of establishing a meaningful relationship between Lore fans and the people within Narrative if the two areas we're *allowed* to talk with them about either *don't exist right now* or are likely set in stone by the time they *would* get to us?

At least that's how I see it, and I don't see anyone from Narrative telling me otherwise.
This is precisely what my previous statement was meant to convey.

It baffles me that it took you *two weeks* to convey this despite numerous unanswered questions on your original post, as well as a separate post with 158 upvotes that expresses disappointment in your words.

My favorite part about that post is that Jaredan is a senior editor, but he doesn't know which members of the narrative team were around six months ago or whether there are even any who have been around that long. At the very least, he cannot answer that question without rambling about something that *sounds* similar but is in fact completely unrelated.
